3 LORs and no idea how people know if they are truly strong or not. I assume they are. 1 from a professor in both my Community College and 1 in my UG College, 1 from my PI whom I did 3 years of undergraduate research with. 1 case report publication, 2 in progress with typed manuscripts with my name on them. 1 first author review also manuscript nearly ready but not submitted. So 3 publications in the wings, which doesn't help at all. No GRE submitted/ taken, 3.43 GPA held down by a 2.0 GPA (33 credits)  from my first years in college. If only my most recent GPA was considered (after 4 years off of college) it would be a 3.8 GPA.  It is complemented all together by an all together GPA for science and math of 3.7. But this gets into the weeds and schools hate the "weeds" in my experience. Self Identified as a Gay student with "a male partner" in one of my essay responses. So happy for all those who received an interview. I wish you all the best as this program is amazing and I hear Seattle is the best! The program suggested you reach out to ask for reasons for denials when you look online at the application site, but when I contacted them they said they do not do this. Just a heads up.

Thank you, too, for submitting your application to the University of Washington Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB) graduate program. After an extensive process that included 3 different levels of review, we are sorry to inform you that your application was not selected for an interview with the MCB program. The number and quality of graduate applicants to the MCB program were extraordinary this year, and our difficult decision concerning your application was reached through careful, holistic consideration of all applications and their merits.

Thank you for applying to the MCB graduate program at the UW, as we recognize that expenditures of money and time to do so can be considerable. Our process has been thorough and, in fairness to all applicants, all decisions are final. There are no appeals after our committee has decided.

We wish you well in your future educational endeavors, and hope that you continue to pursue a graduate education, here or at another world-class university.

They finally responded to my status request with:
"Thank you for your email.  The admission committee has finished the initial review of the applications and selected a group of students to interview.  Your application has been placed in the waitlist. We will contact you soon with the final decision."

To the poster below about being 99% sure, I 100% agree with your assessment. Mine also says 'under review'. What's even worse they don't even respond to their e-mails when you ask for a status. Even if they are not permitted to reveal this information, I would rather they explicitly say this rather than ignore me and other students that have inquired.

I'm 99% sure I was rejected (seeing as though most interviews were scheduled before Christmas and I didn't receive one).

However, my application still says "under review" as of today. I am totally fine with the rejection, I just wish they were sent out in a more timely manner, as waiting this long seems very unprofessional, to say the least.

(response in 3 days after on-cite interview!)
Interview time: 2/3-2/4

I am writing this because I always questioned whether my background would allow me to get into grad school, and it did! This is for other people who are worried about whether they will be taken seriously among other people with their Master's degrees and who have dedicated their post-undergraduate years to research and field work. I was admitted to the program without a Master's degree, and I did not spend any time after undergrad working in the field or doing intensive research. I graduated in 2013 and have worked in several industries since, including docu*entary film and government. I conducted research and field work during undergrad. I currently work in an environmental government sector, and I also volunteer in a genetics lab. I think knowing what you want to do and being confident about your background will help you tell a strong, compelling story!

column14: 9.0/10.0 cgpa, 4th straight reject, should have given GATE instead, at least the IIT's are way more fair than American universities in admissions.

Thank you for your application for the Biology graduate program at the California Institute of Technology. After carefully reviewing your application, the faculty has decided that they are unable to grant you admission. As you know, Caltech is a small school and as such we are able to admit only a small percentage of the applicants who apply each year. In many cases we are unable to offer admission to highly qualified candidates because of limited space and facilities, or because their interests do not coincide sufficiently well with the needs and interests of our faculty. rnYour record and qualifications are very good, and we have no doubt of your ability to earn an advanced degree and that you will have a successful career.  We wish you the best of luck in your future endeavors. rnBest Regards,rnCaltech Graduate Studies rnrn
Contacted the graduate admin for status update. All offers sent out and waiting responses.

I received an email inviting me for an interview on March 4th, 2016, and I attended the interview day on March 18th. Very friendly and small program! I attended several interviews at more "prestigious" universities but I am going to pick this program.  It has a fantastic "small" feel and a great emphasis on both teaching and research. Offers a $24,200 stipend and 50% paid of health insurance. Perfect for future teachers and a fantastic success rate for alumni! 3+ years of prior research experience.

Offers a $24,200 stipend and 50% paid of health insurance. Perfect for future teachers and a fantastic success rate for alumni!

Checked the website and saw the decision letter. Rejection never feels good, but I have already received good offers and was no longer considering attending this program. All in all, I found this program very disrespectul to applicants. The decisions took way too long, I was interviewed on Jan 6 and told it would take 2 weeks to hear back from the program, when that didn't happen, I emailed the program and was told it would take another few weeks and that I was very near their top choice. However, it took over 6 weeks for them to make a decision, and they didn't even have the courtesy to send me an email, had to learn for myself on their website.

They're simply too disrespectful with applicants. I don't mind the rejection as much as their lack of good manners. First, they said results would be available within 6 to 10 weeks; they were a month late when I emailed, no answer, then tried POI again (who already wasn't answering a single one-line email, even after saying that I would be a good asset to her laboratory with the experience I had) and she didn't even bother answering again, she simply forwarded the email to the coordinator so that she could see it and reply. If you're thinking about applying to this place think twice, they may treat you like sh** and get your money.

Was sent an email to check website. Then a few days later was sent a follow up email stating I was on a wait list for three professors..however they each were only taking 1 student and those students had accepted. Very nice of them to send the follow up email.

I had the strangest experience with this school, so in hindsight, I'm relieved that I wasn't admitted. Early in the admissions cycle, I reached out to two professors with whom I was loosely interested in working. I set up several phone interviews with one, who continuously had to cancel them last minute and then never got back to me in the end. I ultimately schedule a phone interview with the second professors, which was also postponed once, but I did finally speak to him and our interests matched well and he said he would like to organize a visit for me. After this phone call, I reached out to him a few times to schedule a visit but he never got back in touch. Then I received a rejection letter pretty late in the cycle (3/28), which I wasn't surprised by and I had already long given up on this school because the practices seemed very unprofessional. In any event, I accepted an offer from my top choice, so either way, I am happy for those of you who have found a home at this institution and I hope that they have been more accommodating for you than they were for me. :)

column1: Internation Max Planck Research School For Cell, Developmental & Systems Biology
column14: The interview week started Monday.. and the offers were given out on Friday. Extremely well organised, consisted of interviews with PIs of interest, lab visits and more interviews with selection committees. It really helps to visit an institute and speak to the people you might want to work with. But of course, the program doesn't have lab rotations or coursework like most American PhD programs. But you get to finish in 3 years.. Good for people who know exactly what question they want to work on and don't mind choosing a lab to work in without any rotations.

The materials you submitted with your application have been carefully reviewed by the admissions committee, but we are unable to recommend you for admission.
The UC Berkeley campus has a strict enrollment ceiling, and we are thus very limited in the number of new students we may admit each year. The admissions committee has the difficult task of selecting students with the strongest overall records from a large pool of well-qualified applicants. Unfortunately, this may result in not being able to accept many applicants who are capable of excellent academic work.
We appreciate the interest you have shown in UC Berkeley and wish you success in achieving your academic goals."

Biochemistry, Cell And Developmental Biology (BCDB), Graduate Division
column14: This year's pool of applicants was both very large and highly competitive, and our review of applicants' credentials and interests left us with difficult decisions.  Graduate admissions decisions are based on the applicants' preparation for advanced study and on judgments about their strength relative to other applicants in the pool.  The deliberations also consider how applicants and their proposed areas of study and research match up with faculty and with other resources and opportunities available at Emory over the next several years.  All applicants' files, including yours, received a thorough review, and after careful consideration we have decided not to extend you an offer of admission.
Great!!! Very competitive

Thanks for the responses- I wish everyone good luck!

Wow look at all the Biology people now beginning to post. I emailed these guys 3 times since March and they kept telling me that they were STILL making decisions. So I called them up on the phone and they told me again I need to wait. I'm lucky that my other choice is not until the end of April....

to the poster below, they told me the same thing for my program. As soon as they know they'll tell me. The problem here is that most programs want a response by the 15th, it's already the 12th... Your application has been reviewed and has been placed on the wait list.
The admissions committee will decide this week if there are any spots left
for students from the wait list.
If you do not receive an invitation by April 1, it is unlikely that any will
be sent after that date. The committee usually does not officially close the
application season until April 15. Once the committee officially closes the
application season, an email is sent to all applicants who have not received
offers that all the spots have been filled.
